stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on designing 'Course 15', a level with a 'retrofuturism' theme, focusing on level layout, platforming elements like monorails, and a bouncy platform mechanic. A significant portion of the stream was dedicated to a collaborative brainstorming session with the chat to design the level's boss, which evolved from 'The Blob' to a complex giant squid encounter. Kaze also discussed the recent release of a new demo for Course 1 and debugged a critical bug preventing the game from booting on real hardware.

development_findings.summary: The level being worked on (Course 15) is explicitly themed around 'retrofuturism', drawing visual inspiration from 1960s sci-fi concepts of space colonies, with monorails being a key element.
development_findings.quote: By the way, the theme for this is like retrofuturism. So we want this to look like a space colony as imagined in 1960.

development_findings.summary: Kaze deliberately restricted Mario's moveset, such as the spin move, to prevent it from becoming overpowered and to function as a 'safety move' for recovering from mistakes.
development_findings.quote: I keep forgetting I changed it so you can only spin or ground pound dive at any time. Because otherwise the movement is too broken.

development_findings.summary: Kaze attempted a technical experiment to improve performance by executing code from the cartridge instead of RAM. The experiment failed to yield the expected benefits, and the reason remains unknown.
development_findings.quote: My idea was we run the code directly from the cartridge instead of from RAM. So that way we would prevent using the RAM bus to execute code. ... Unfortunately it did not and I don't know why.

development_findings.summary: A major technical bug was discovered where the game fails to boot on real hardware via an EverDrive X7. Kaze is actively debugging the issue, suspecting it relates to how the flashcart handles cache.
development_findings.quote: I found out today that my game does not boot on the EverDrive X7. So right now I'm trying a build where I invalidate the entire RAM before I boot the game... I noticed that the EverDrive is not clearing beta cache.

development_findings.summary: Kaze received concept art from a fan on Twitter for some assets and confirmed he intends to use the fan's design in the game, showing community involvement in the creative process.
Kaze is conscious of not overusing references to other games like Sonic Adventure 2, wanting the project to maintain its own creative identity.
development_findings.quote: If I reference it too much people are gonna be like this guy just keeps copying SA2, does he even have an original thought?

development_findings.summary: Kaze favors environmental and implicit storytelling over explicit lore dumps for building the game's narrative.
development_findings.quote: If anything, we would want implicit storytelling.

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds a strong, contrarian view on traditional color theory, stating he doesn't use it and believes it's an arbitrary, non-functional set of rules.
context_findings.quote: I don't think color theory is real. I think it's all bullshit. I think color theory is a principle made goal, that doesn't actually function as a goal, and people pretend it's a goal, but it shouldn't be.

context_findings.summary: Kaze dislikes the social platitude of asking "how are you" and uses Immanuel Kant's categorical imperative to philosophically deconstruct whether he should engage in a polite social norm that he personally finds annoying and wishes others wouldn't do.
context_findings.quote: According to Kant, should I ask people how they are or should I not? Technically, I should not, right? But that just makes the world a worse place for everyone else in it. So does that really make sense?

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes that in group conversations, contributions should be meaningful and concise due to the value of shared time, expressing frustration with those who don't adhere to this principle.
context_findings.quote: The more people are in a conversation, the more valuable each second of audio bandwidth is. So the more people are in a conversation, the more valuable each contribution you do should be. And some people don't understand this.

context_findings.summary: Kaze announced the release of the second demo for the game, containing only Course 1, and mentioned he was pleased with the positive public reception so far.
Kaze expressed that he was feeling very distracted during the stream, apologizing for it and attributing the slow progress to the distraction.

biobak.summary: Kaze relies on Biobak to interpret his design intentions and create appropriate textures, showing trust in his artistic skills and understanding of the project's vision.
biobak.quote: I'm sure Biomec can find a better texture for what I'm trying to convey in here.

biobak.summary: Biobak engages with Kaze in casual, philosophical discussions during the stream, indicating a friendly rapport beyond just game development tasks.
biobak.quote: Right, but that's not what Immanuel Kant says, Biobak. That's what I'm getting at.

zeina.summary: Kaze is collaborating with Zeina (referred to as Aza) on a side project related to SimpleFlips, indicating a creative partnership that extends beyond the main game.
zeina.quote: By the way, Aza, you're still here. Is there any progress on our SimpleFlips entry thing?

zeina.summary: Zeina is involved in informal, fun side projects ('shitposts') with Kaze and other collaborators, highlighting a playful dynamic within their working relationship.
zeina.quote: There's one very stupid shitpost that I am going to make with Doriel and Aza.

key_stories.title: The Collaborative Evolution of a Boss
key_stories.summary: The design for the retrofuturism boss underwent a rapid, collaborative evolution during the stream. Starting as a simple homage to 1950s sci-fi, it morphed through community suggestions into a complex encounter with a giant tentacled monster, with Kaze steering the mechanics toward active platforming and away from passive boss patterns.
key_stories.challenge: To design a thematically appropriate and mechanically engaging boss fight for the 'retrofuturism' level.
key_stories.process: Kaze initially proposed 'The Blob' from 1950s sci-fi films. A community member suggested 'Sluggy the Unshaven' from Yoshi's Island, which Kaze briefly adopted. This evolved through further community feedback into a giant squid monster attacking from Fortnite-style rifts. The team then brainstormed various ways to damage it, rejecting ideas that involved waiting in favor of active engagement.
key_stories.outcome: The team converged on a concept for a giant squid-like boss that attacks from rifts. The player will be cued by dynamic lighting from the rifts and will attack the boss's vulnerable eyes when it appears, creating an active, platforming-centric encounter rather than a passive waiting game.
key_stories.key_quote: I don't like waiting for a damageable face like this. I think I would much prefer it if you had to do platforming to get to it.

open_questions.context: Kaze discovered the game doesn't boot on an EverDrive X7 flashcart, suspecting an issue with the hardware not clearing the 'beta cache.' He was running a test to see if manually invalidating RAM would fix it.
questions: What was the ultimate root cause of the EverDrive X7 boot failure?
Can you walk through the technical steps you took to diagnose and fix this hardware-specific issue?
How important is real hardware compatibility to you, and how does that goal shape your development and testing process?

open_questions.context: Kaze described a failed technical experiment where he tried to run game code directly from the cartridge instead of from RAM, hoping to improve performance by freeing up the RAM bus. He stated that it didn't work and he didn't know why.
questions: Did you ever investigate further and discover why running code from the cartridge didn't improve performance as expected?
What did you learn from that experiment, even though it failed?
Can you share other examples of ambitious technical ideas you've explored for this project that ended up being dead ends?

open_questions.topic: Collaboration with Zeina (Aza) on Side Projects
open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned collaborating with 'Aza' (Zeina) on a 'SimpleFlips entry thing' and a 'stupid shitpost' project with Aza and another person named Doriel.
questions: Could you tell us more about the 'SimpleFlips entry' project you're working on with Zeina?
How do you and Zeina navigate the dynamic of being both personal partners and creative collaborators?
What is the nature of these informal 'shitpost' projects? How do they fit into your creative life?

open_questions.context: An infinite coin bug was reported by a player of the new demo. Kaze theorized it was caused by grabbing a flag from the very bottom, causing an underflow, and stated that he believed he fixed it on stream.
questions: Was your on-stream fix for the infinite coin bug the final solution?
How do you prioritize and triage bugs reported from public demos while also trying to make progress on new content?
What's the most unexpected or bizarre bug that's been discovered by the community so far?
